org.jtrim.collections

Interface RefList<E>

  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements in this list
    All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.Collection<E>, java.lang.Iterable<E>, java.util.List<E>, RefCollection<E>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    RefLinkedList

    public interface RefList<E>
extends java.util.List<E>, RefCollection<E>
    Defines a list whose elements can be referenced independently. These element references remain valid even after the list was modified.

    The references can be used for various purposes, like inserting a new element after or before a given element, incrementing or decrementing the position of the element is the list.

    Unlike general List implementations, implementations of this interface in general are not allowed to have more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements. Some implementations may ignore this restriction but there is no general rule how methods should work when the size of such lists exceed Integer#MAX_VALUE.

    Thread safety

    Implementations of this interface are not required to be thread-safe and in general cannot be modified concurrently by multiple concurrent threads. However reading by multiple concurrent threads are allowed. Note that accessing the element references of a RefList is equivalent to accessing the collection itself regarding thread safety.

    Synchronization transparency

    The methods of this interface are required to be synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
    See Also:
    RefLinkedList

      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static interface  RefList.ElementRef<E>
      Defines a reference to an element of a RefList.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      RefList.ElementRef<E> addFirstGetReference(E element)
      Adds a new element as the first (with zero index) element of this list and returns a reference to it.
      RefList.ElementRef<E> addGetReference(int index, E element)
      Adds a new element to this list with the given index and returns a reference to it.
      RefList.ElementRef<E> addLastGetReference(E element)
      Adds a new element as the last (with size() - 1 index) element of this list and returns a reference to it.
      RefList.ElementRef<E> findFirstReference(E element)
      Returns the reference to the element equivalent (based on the equals method) to the given element with the lowest index.
      RefList.ElementRef<E> findLastReferece(E element)
      Returns the reference to the element equivalent (based on the equals method) to the given element with the highest index.
      RefList.ElementRef<E> getFirstReference()
      Returns the reference to the first element of this list or null if this list is empty.
      RefList.ElementRef<E> getLastReference()
      Returns the reference to the last element of this list or null if this list is empty.
      RefList.ElementRef<E> getReference(int index)
      Returns the reference to the element at the given index.

    • Method Detail

      • findFirstReference

        RefList.ElementRef<E> findFirstReference(E element)
        Returns the reference to the element equivalent (based on the equals method) to the given element with the lowest index.
        Parameters:
        element - the element to be looked for in this list. This argument can be null if this collection permits null elements. In case this implementation does not permit null elements but accept null for this argument, it must return null if null is passed for this argument.
        Returns:
        the reference to the element equivalent to the given element with the lowest index or null if no such element was found
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - implementations may throw this exception if this collection does not permit null elements. However even in this case, an implementation is not required to raise this exception.

      • findLastReferece

        RefList.ElementRef<E> findLastReferece(E element)
        Returns the reference to the element equivalent (based on the equals method) to the given element with the highest index.
        Parameters:
        element - the element to be looked for in this list. This argument can be null if this collection permits null elements. In case this implementation does not permit null elements but accept null for this argument, it must return null if null is passed for this argument.
        Returns:
        the reference to the element equivalent to the given element with the highest index or null if no such element was found
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - implementations may throw this exception if this collection does not permit null elements. However even in this case, an implementation is not required to raise this exception.

        RefList.ElementRef<E> getFirstReference()

        Returns:
        the reference to the first element of this list or null if this list is empty

      • getReference

        RefList.ElementRef<E> getReference(int index)
        Returns the reference to the element at the given index.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the requested element. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero and lesser than the size of this list.
        Returns:
        the reference to the element at the given index. This method may never return null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - thrown if the specified index points to an element outside of this list

      • addFirstGetReference

        RefList.ElementRef<E> addFirstGetReference(E element)
        Adds a new element as the first (with zero index) element of this list and returns a reference to it. A subsequent call to getFirstReference() will return the same reference. The newly added element can later be replaced or removed by the returned reference even if this collection was modified since then.

        This method is effectively equivalent to calling: addGetReference(0, element).

        Parameters:
        element - the new element to be added to this list as the first element. This argument can be null only if this collection supports null elements.
        Returns:
        the reference which can be used to replace or remove the newly added element. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - thrown if this collection does not support adding new elements to it (possibly because it is readonly)
        java.lang.ClassCastException - thrown if the class of the specified element prevents it from being added to this collection. Note that since generics are implemented using erasure, this cannot always be verified.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified element is null and this collection does not permit null elements
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if some property of the element prevents it from being added to this collection
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if the element cannot be added at this time due to insertion restrictions

      • addLastGetReference

        RefList.ElementRef<E> addLastGetReference(E element)
        Adds a new element as the last (with size() - 1 index) element of this list and returns a reference to it. A subsequent call to getLastReference() will return the same reference. The newly added element can later be replaced or removed by the returned reference even if this collection was modified since then.

        This method is effectively equivalent to calling: addGetReference(0, size()).

        Parameters:
        element - the new element to be added to this list as the last element. This argument can be null only if this collection supports null elements.
        Returns:
        the reference which can be used to replace or remove the newly added element. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - thrown if this collection does not support adding new elements to it (possibly because it is readonly)
        java.lang.ClassCastException - thrown if the class of the specified element prevents it from being added to this collection. Note that since generics are implemented using erasure, this cannot always be verified.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified element is null and this collection does not permit null elements
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if some property of the element prevents it from being added to this collection
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if the element cannot be added at this time due to insertion restrictions

      • addGetReference

        RefList.ElementRef<E> addGetReference(int index,
                                    E element)
        Adds a new element to this list with the given index and returns a reference to it. A subsequent call to getReference(index) will return the same reference. The newly added element can later be replaced or removed by the returned reference even if this collection was modified since then. To append the element to the end of this list specify the size of this list as the index.
        Parameters:
        index - the index to which the new element is to be inserted. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero and lesser than or equal to zero.
        element - the new element to be added to this list at the given index. This argument can be null only if this collection supports null elements.
        Returns:
        the reference which can be used to replace or remove the newly added element. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - thrown if this collection does not support adding new elements to it (possibly because it is readonly)
        java.lang.ClassCastException - thrown if the class of the specified element prevents it from being added to this collection. Note that since generics are implemented using erasure, this cannot always be verified.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified element is null and this collection does not permit null elements
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if some property of the element prevents it from being added to this collection
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if the element cannot be added at this time due to insertion restrictions
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of range (index &lt; 0 || index &gt; size()
